questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50 mL/hour

 

The normal insensible water loss is 50 mL/hour.

 

Some of the water losses cannot be precisely regulated. For example, there is a continuous loss of water by evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin, which together account for about 700 ml/day of water loss under normal conditions. This is termed insensible water loss because we are not consciously aware of it, even though it occurs continually in all living humans. It is about 700 mL/day or 50 mL/hour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal insensible water loss is approximately 50 mL/hour, resulting from evaporation through the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin.

questions.text:
A woman has vomiting whenever she eats spicy food. Arrange the sequence of events during vomiting? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. LES is open and UES is closed.
  2. Strong contractions in the stomach.
  3. Inspiration against a closed glottis.
  4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter.
  5. LES opens and UES opens.
  6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine.
     

LES: Lower esophageal sphincter

 

UES: Upper esophageal sphincter
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6, 4, 2, 3, 1, 5

 

The correct sequence of events during vomiting is:

 

6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine: This begins the vomiting process, moving contents from the ileum towards the stomach.

 

4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter: This allows the contents to move from the small intestine into the stomach.

 

2. Strong contractions in the stomach: These contractions help to force the stomach contents upwards.

 

3. Inspiration against a closed glottis: This involves taking a deep breath with the glottis closed, increasing intra-abdominal pressure.

 

1. LES is open and UES is closed: Initially, the LES opens to allow the contents to move into the esophagus, while the UES remains closed.

 

5. LES opens and UES opens: Finally, both sphincters open to allow the contents to be expelled through the mouth.

 

Act of vomiting involves series of movements that takes place in GI tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sequence of events in act of vomiting:

 

  1. Beginning of antiperistalsis, which runs from ileum towards the mouth through the intestine, pushing the intestinal contents into the stomach within few minutes. Velocity of the antiperistalsis is about 2 to 3 cm/second
  2. Deep inspiration followed by temporary cessation of breathing
  3. Closure of glottis
  4. Upward and forward movement of larynx and hyoid bone
  5. Elevation of soft palate
  6. Contraction of diaphragm and abdominal muscles with a characteristic jerk, resulting in elevation of intra-abdominal pressure
  7. Compression of the stomach between diaphragm and abdominal wall leading to rise in intragastric pressure
  8. Simultaneous relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter, esophagus and upper esophageal sphincter
  9. Forceful expulsion of gastric contents (vomitus) through esophagus, pharynx and mouth.

questions.text: All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serotonin

 

Explanation

 

All of the options listed increase gastric acid secretion except serotonin.

 

Gastric Acid Secretion:

 

  • Parietal Cells: Located deep in the oxyntic glands of the main body of the stomach, parietal cells are the only cells that secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl).
  • Enterochromaffin-Like (ECL) Cells: These cells lie in the deep recesses of the oxyntic glands and release histamine in direct contact with the parietal cells of the glands. The rate of HCl formation and secretion by the parietal cells is directly related to the amount of histamine secreted by the ECL cells.

 

Stimulation of ECL Cells:

 

  1. Gastrin: The most potent stimulator of histamine secretion from ECL cells.
  2. Acetylcholine: Released from stomach vagal nerve endings, stimulates ECL cells.
  3. Histamine: Released by ECL cells, directly stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl.

 

Role of Serotonin:

 

  • Serotonin: Localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract, serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It also stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrin: Incorrect. Gastrin increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Option B. Histamine: Incorrect. Histamine increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Option C. Acetylcholine: Incorrect. Acetylcholine increases gastric acid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion, while gastrin, histamine, and acetylcholine stimulate it. Serotonin also stimulates mucus production and increases intestinal motility, acting as an enteric neurotransmitter.

questions.text: Which receptor helps in improvement of insulin resistance in Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus with regular exercise and physical activity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GLUT4

 

GLUT4 is a glucose transporter found primarily in adipose tissues and striated muscles (skeletal and cardiac). It is insulin-dependent, meaning its activity increases in response to insulin. During exercise, the translocation of GLUT4 to the cell membrane is stimulated, enhancing glucose uptake into cells even in the absence of insulin. This mechanism is crucial in improving insulin sensitivity and combating insulin resistance, particularly in individuals with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM2). Regular physical activity enhances this effect, leading to better glucose control and reduction of hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GLUT1: This glucose transporter is found in many tissues, including the brain, and is responsible for basal glucose uptake. It is not significantly influenced by insulin and does not play a direct role in improving insulin resistance in DM2.

 

Option C. GLUT2: GLUT2 is primarily found in the liver, pancreas, kidneys, and intestines. It functions in glucose sensing and plays a role in glucose homeostasis but is not directly involved in the insulin-dependent improvement of glucose uptake seen in DM2.

 

Option D. GLUT3: GLUT3 is a high-affinity glucose transporter found predominantly in neurons. It ensures a constant supply of glucose to the brain, but it is not insulin-dependent and does not have a significant role in the management of insulin resistance in DM2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT4 is the insulin-dependent glucose transporter that plays a key role in improving insulin resistance with regular exercise and physical activity.

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. Which of the following is the best representation of compliance between the three lungs? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) В>А>С

 

  • ﻿﻿The above graph is a pressure-volume relationship showing the relationship between the work of breathing and lung mechanics.
  • ﻿﻿The graphs show the lung compliance which is the change in lung volume with change in intrapleural pressure.
  • A steeper curve implies more compliance while a flatter curve implies less compliance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steepness of the pressure-volume curve indicates lung compliance. In this graph, lung B has the highest compliance, lung A has moderate compliance, and lung C has the lowest compliance.

choices.text: MRI to rule out enlarged heart

questions.text: The parents notice that their child is tired and that he has shortness of breath on climbing stairs and while lying down. What is the first investigation that you would do? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest x-ray

 

The first investigation to be done for a child who feels shortness of breath on climbing stairs and in the supine position is a chest x-ray.

 

The child having shortness of breath on dyspnea on exertion worsened in the supine position is orthopnea could be suggestive of congestive heart failure.

 

Causes -

 

  1. Respiratory causes include asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD), pneumonia, and pulmonary embolism.
  2. Cardiovascular causes include congestive heart failure (CH), pulmonary edema, valvular heart defect, and pulmonary hypertension.

 

Evaluation

 

  • Oxygen saturation at rest and during physical activity
  • Chest x-ray is the first diagnostic test as pulmonary pathology or pulmonary edema and signs of CHF may be seen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: An echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac cause if the chest X-ray is abnormal

 

Option C: Spirometry to assess lung function when the chest x-ray is normal.

 

Option D: Cardiac MRI (Magnetic resonance imaging) is an emerging modality done to look for cardiomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a child presenting with shortness of breath on exertion and orthopnea, the first investigation should be a chest x-ray to evaluate potential pulmonary pathology and signs of congestive heart failure.

questions.text: On thyroid function test analysis, TSH value was much higher than normal with low free T4. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Primary hypothyroidism

 

HYPOTHYROIDISM

 

Types:

 

  1. Primary Hypothyroidism - Increased TSH with low T4 levels.
  2. Secondary hypothyroidism - TSH can be low, normal or elevated slightly. The latter is due to secretion of immune-active but bio-active forms of TSH. Confirmation of diagnosis is done by detecting low levels of unbound T4.

 

Evaluation of Hypothyroidism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical hypothyroidism: Incorrect because subclinical hypothyroidism would show an elevated TSH but normal free T4 levels.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: Incorrect as hyperthyroidism would typically present with low TSH and high free T4 levels.

 

Option C. Secondary hypothyroidism: Incorrect for this scenario because secondary hypothyroidism involves a problem with pituitary TSH production, which does not typically result in a significantly elevated TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary hypothyroidism is characterized by high TSH and low free T4 levels, indicating a failure of the thyroid gland itself to produce sufficient hormones.

questions.text: What is the function of Tubuloglomerular feedback? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Regulate GFR

 

Tubuloglomerular feedback regulates glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

 

The major function of autoregulation in the kidneys is to maintain a relatively constant GFR and to allow precise control of renal excretion of water and solutes.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease plasma sodium: Incorrect as the primary function of tubuloglomerular feedback is not to decrease plasma sodium but to adjust renal blood flow and filtration to maintain stable GFR.

 

Option C. Increase plasma volume: Incorrect, tubuloglomerular feedback does not directly function to increase plasma volume; rather, it regulates the filtration rate to maintain balance.

 

Option D. Decrease tubular secretion: Incorrect, this feedback specifically regulates GFR, not tubular secretion processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubuloglomerular feedback is an adaptive mechanism in the kidneys that helps regulate GFR in response to changes in blood pressure and filtrate flow rate, ensuring stable renal function and homeostasis.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory receptors are responsible for tactile discrimination? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meissner's corpuscle

 

Meissner's Corpuscles are responsible for discriminative touch.

 

 

 

Meissner’s corpuscle

 

Touch receptor with great sensitivity

An elongated encapsulated nerve ending of a large (type AB. myelinated sensory nerve fiber. Inside the capsulation are many branching terminal nerve filaments.

 

Present in the non-hairy parts of the skin and are particularly abundant in the fingertips, lips, and other areas of the skin where one’s ability to discern spatial locations of touch sensations is highly developed.

 

These are responsible for-Two Point discrimination, Fine touch and Slow vibration

 

If the question asks - Best for 2 point discrimination/ best for Braille reading/ static 2 point discrimination - the answer is Merkel


If the question asks - Most common/ most abundant/ maximum on glabrous skin/ primary / dynamic 2 point discrimination - the answer is Meissners
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Merkel Disc: Allows one to determine continuous touch of objects against the skin.

 

Option B. Ruffini End Organ: Responsible for temperature sensation.

 

Option C. Pacinian Corpuscle: Responsible for pressure and crude touch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meissner's corpuscles are specialized for discriminative touch, enabling precise location and detection of fine tactile stimuli. They are most abundant in areas where tactile acuity is high, such as the fingertips and lips

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High Glucose

 

Rheumatoid pleural effusion, associated with rheumatoid arthritis, typically presents with low glucose levels, making high glucose the correct answer as it is not a characteristic found in such effusions. The low glucose in rheumatoid pleural effusion is due to increased metabolic activity of leukocytes and pleural cells which consume glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RA factor: The presence of RA factor (Rheumatoid factor) in pleural fluid is commonly seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid factor is an autoantibody found in the blood of approximately 80% of adults with rheumatoid arthritis. Its presence in pleural fluid reflects the systemic inflammatory nature of the disease.

 

Option B. Cholesterol crystals: Cholesterol crystals in the pleural fluid are indicative of a long-standing effusion, which can occur in chronic rheumatoid pleuritis. These crystals form as the pleural fluid becomes more concentrated over time due to the chronic nature of the inflammation.

 

Option D. High LDH: High levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in the pleural fluid are a common feature of exudative effusions, including those caused by rheumatoid arthritis. LDH is an enzyme present in most cells and is released into the pleural fluid when cells are damaged or destroyed, reflecting the inflammatory processes occurring in rheumatoid pleuritis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defect in which of the following cell?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Type 2 pneumocytes

 

One of the most characteristic findings in respiratory distress syndrome is failure of the respiratory epithelium to secrete adequate quantities of surfactant, a substance normally secreted into the alveoli that decreases the surface tension of the alveolar fluid, therefore allowing the alveoli to open easily during inspiration.

 

The surfactant-secreting cells are type II alveolar epithelial cells.

 

Production of the surfactant begins by week 20-24. It appears in the amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 weeks of gestation. Mature levels of the pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 weeks of gestation.

 

Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase production of surfactant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 pneumocytes: Incorrect because although Type 1 pneumocytes cover a large surface area of the alveoli and are involved in the gas exchange process, they do not produce surfactant. The defect in Type 1 pneumocytes generally leads to issues with the structural integrity of the alveolar walls, not surfactant deficiency.

 

Option C. Alveolar capillary endothelial cells: Incorrect as these cells line the alveolar capillaries and are involved in the blood-air barrier for gas exchange. Defects in these cells can lead to issues like pulmonary edema but are not directly related to surfactant production or respiratory distress syndrome due to surfactant deficiency.

 

Option D. Bronchial mucosal epithelial cells: Incorrect because these cells line the bronchial passages and are primarily involved in mucous production and the removal of particulates and pathogens from inhaled air. They are not involved in surfactant production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, is commonly due to insufficient surfactant production by Type 2 pneumocytes. This deficiency impedes the lungs' ability to expand properly, leading to respiratory distress. Management often includes the administration of exogenous surfactant and supportive care to enhance lung function until the infant's own cells can produce adequate surfactant.

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.text: A patient met with a road traffic accident and developed a cervical spine injury. The fracture fragment had pierced the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract. Which of the following findings is seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception

 

Explanation

 

The above clinical scenario depicts transection of the spinal cord in the lateral aspect of the dorsal column would affect the fasciculus cuneatus. This lesion would result in absence of ipsilateral proprioception of the arm.

 

 

The fibers in the dorsal column are arranged in such a manner that the sacral segments are positioned most medially and those from the cervical segments are positioned most laterally.

 

These are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus gracilis - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb
  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus cuneatus - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral upper limb.

 

Fasciculus Gracilis and Cuneatus functions:

 

  1. Fine touch
  2. Tactile localization
  3. Tactile discrimination
  4. Vibration

 

This patient with an injury to the lateral part of the cervical cord's dorsal column tract will have damaged fasciculus cuneatus. This would result in loss of touch, vibration, and proprioception in the arm of the same side of the lesion.

 

function below the level of injury. The clue to solving this question is that the question mentions that the damage is to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception: This would be seen if the fasciculus gracilis was affected, which is responsible for carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb.

 

Option B. Absence of fine motor movement of fingers: This would be a result of damage to the corticospinal tract, which carries motor information.

 

Option D. Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception: Proprioception is carried by the dorsal column pathway, and it is affected ipsilaterally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract in the cervical spine region results in the loss of ipsilateral arm proprioception due to the involvement of the fasciculus cuneatus. This emphasizes the importance of the dorsal column in carrying proprioceptive and fine tactile information from the upper limbs.

 

Additional Information

 

Brown Sequard Syndrome (Hemi-sectioning of spinal cord)

 

  • I/L loss of Fine touch
  • C/L loss of Pain & Temperature
  • I/L loss of Proprioception
  • I/L motor paralysis

questions.text: All of the following ions have decreased concentration on the luminal side of late proximal convoluted tubule except: [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urea

 

In the late proximal tubule, urea concentration actually increases relative to plasma levels due to preferential water reabsorption and its lower reabsorption rate compared to other solutes. This creates a concentration gradient that becomes important for the medullary concentrating mechanism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Potassium: Incorrect. Potassium concentration decreases due to active reabsorption through Na⁺-K⁺-ATPase and paracellular pathways in the proximal tubule.

 

Option C. Sodium: Incorrect. Sodium concentration decreases significantly through various transport mechanisms including Na⁺-K⁺-ATPase, sodium-glucose cotransport, and sodium-amino acid cotransport.

 

Option D. Phosphate: Incorrect. Phosphate concentration decreases due to sodium-dependent phosphate cotransporters (NaPi-2a and NaPi-2c) in the proximal tubule.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding that urea becomes concentrated in the late proximal tubule due to differential reabsorption rates between water and urea, while other ions like sodium, potassium, and phosphate are actively reabsorbed, leading to their decreased luminal concentrations.

questions.text: "a" wave on JVP is for: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrial contraction

 

 

The "a" wave on the jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing represents atrial contraction. This wave occurs when the right atrium contracts, pushing blood into the right ventricle. It is the first positive deflection in the JVP waveform and is a key component in assessing right atrial pressure and function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial filling: Incorrect. Atrial filling is represented by the v wave, which occurs as the atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole.

 

Option C. Ventricular relaxation: Incorrect. Ventricular relaxation corresponds to the x descent and y descent in the JVP tracing.

 

Option D. Ventricular filling: Incorrect. Ventricular filling is associated with the y descent.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Covers the active site on actin

questions.text: Which attribute accurately describes myosin within muscle fibers? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Exhibits ATPase activity

 

Explanation:

 

Myosin forms the thick filaments in muscle and possesses ATPase activity in its globular head region. The myosin head contains both an actin-binding site and a catalytic site that hydrolyzes ATP. This ATPase activity is essential for the power stroke during muscle contraction, as ATP hydrolysis provides the energy needed for the conformational change in the myosin head that generates force.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Component of thin filaments: Myosin constitutes the thick filaments, not the thin filaments. The thin filaments are composed of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin.
  • Option b. Covers the active site on actin: This is the function of tropomyosin, not myosin. Tropomyosin covers the myosin-binding sites on actin during muscle relaxation, and is displaced when calcium binds to troponin C.
  • Option d. Calcium-binding protein: Calcium binding is the function of troponin C, not myosin. Troponin C contains specific binding sites for calcium that initiate the contractile process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myosin's ATPase activity is fundamental to muscle contraction as it hydrolyzes ATP to generate the energy needed for the power stroke, which creates movement by changing the angle of the myosin head while attached to actin.

questions.text: In the 2 vessels shown below, assume the pressure along both the vessels is the same and both follow linear flow pattern. What will be the amount of blood flow in A compared to B? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8 times

 

According to Poiseuille's law:

 

 

in which F is the rate of blood flow, ∆P is the pressure difference between the ends of the vessel, r is the radius of the vessel, l is length of the vessel, and h is viscosity of the blood.

 

Therefore, blood flow (F) inside the vessel is

 

  • ﻿﻿Directly proportional to the pressure difference
  • ﻿﻿Inversely proportional to the viscosity:
  • ﻿﻿Directly proportional to the fourth power of radius
  • ﻿﻿Inversely proportional to length of the vessel

 

So, if the radius is doubled flow will increase by 2 to the power of 4 = 16

And if the length of the vessel is also doubled, the reduces by half (÷2) = 8

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to Poiseuille's law blood flow (𝐹F) is:

 

  • Directly proportional to the pressure difference (Δ𝑃ΔP)
  • Inversely proportional to the viscosity (𝜂η)
  • Directly proportional to the fourth power of the radius (𝑟4r4)
  • Inversely proportional to the length of the vessel (𝑙l)

questions.text: Which of these hormones have intracellular receptors? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thyroxine

 

  • Thyroxine hormone act by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors.
  • All other hormones mentioned in the options bind to receptors on the cell membrane.
  • Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action.
  • The thyroid hormone receptors are either attached to the DNA genetic strands or located in proximity to them. The thyroid hormone receptor usually forms a heterodimer with retinoid X receptor (RXR) at specific thyroid hormone response elements on the DNA. On binding with thyroid hormone, the receptors become activated and initiate the transcription process.
  • Then large numbers of different types of messenger RNA are formed, followed within another few minutes or hours by RNA translation on the cytoplasmic ribosomes to form hundreds of new intracellular proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epinephrine: Epinephrine binds to adrenergic receptors on the cell membrane, which are G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Option C. Glucagon: Glucagon binds to glucagon receptors on the cell membrane, which are also G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Option D. Parathormone: Parathormone (PTH) binds to PTH receptors on the cell membrane, which are G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroxine acts by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors, initiating transcription and subsequent protein synthesis. This distinguishes it from hormones like epinephrine, glucagon, and parathormone, which bind to receptors on the cell membrane.

choices.text: Rapid filling of the left ventricle

questions.text: The dicrotic notch on the aortic pressure curve is caused by?  (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Closing of the aortic valve

 

Explanation: 

 

The dicrotic notch is a small oscillation or wave that appears in the falling phase of the aortic pressure curve during the cardiac cycle. This notch is specifically caused by vibrations set up when the aortic valve snaps shut. The dicrotic notch occurs at the end of ventricular systole when the aortic pressure exceeds left ventricular pressure, causing the aortic valve to close. This closure creates a brief backward movement of blood and subsequent rebound, generating the characteristic notch in the aortic pressure tracing.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Closing of the mitral valve The mitral valve closes at the beginning of ventricular systole, not during the falling phase of aortic pressure. Mitral valve closure contributes to the first heart sound (S1) and occurs before ejection of blood into the aorta, so it cannot be responsible for the dicrotic notch.
  • Option B. Closing of the tricuspid valve The tricuspid valve closes at the beginning of right ventricular systole, similar to mitral valve closure. It has no direct effect on aortic pressure and occurs much earlier in the cardiac cycle than the dicrotic notch.
  • Option D. Rapid filling of the left ventricle Rapid filling of the left ventricle occurs during early diastole, after the aortic valve has closed. This ventricular filling phase follows the dicrotic notch rather than causing it, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dicrotic notch is a distinctive feature on the aortic pressure curve that specifically marks the moment of aortic valve closure at the end of ventricular systole, representing the transition between systole and diastole.

questions.text: Which ion channels are defective in CFTR gene mutation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cl-

 

The CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene mutation primarily affects chloride ion channels. In cystic fibrosis, the defective CFTR gene leads to the malfunctioning of these chloride channels, which are crucial for maintaining the balance of salt and water on epithelial surfaces such as the lungs and the pancreas. This malfunction results in the production of thick and sticky mucus, leading to the various symptoms associated with cystic fibrosis. The normal functioning CFTR protein allows chloride ions to move in and out of cells, regulating the water content in mucus and other secretions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Na+: Incorrect. While sodium ion transport can be indirectly affected by the dysfunctional chloride channels, the primary defect in cystic fibrosis is related to chloride ions.

 

Option C. K+: Incorrect. Potassium channels are not directly affected by the CFTR gene mutation. The primary defect is specific to chloride ion channels.

 

Option D. Ca2+: Incorrect. Calcium channels are not directly impacted by mutations in the CFTR gene. The main issue in cystic fibrosis lies with chloride ion transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CFTR gene mutations cause defects in chloride ion channels, leading to the symptoms of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Normal gastric secretions contain a glycoprotein called intrinsic factor, secreted by the same parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid. Intrinsic factor must be present for adequate absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. That is, intrinsic factor combines with vitamin B12 in the stomach and protects it from being digested and destroyed as it passes into the small intestine. Then, when the intrinsic factor–vitamin B12 complex reaches the terminal ileum, the intrinsic factor binds with receptors on the ileal epithelial surface. This in turn makes it possible for the vitamin B12 to be absorbed

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid deficiency: Incorrect as the primary site for folate absorption is the jejunum. While partial jejunal resection could impact folate absorption, the redundancy in folate absorption along the small intestine generally compensates unless the resection is extensive.

 

Option C. Gastric ulcer: Incorrect because gastric ulcers are typically related to factors affecting the stomach lining, such as Helicobacter pylori infection or NSAID use, and are not directly caused by resections of the ileum or jejunum.

 

Option D. Constipation: Incorrect as constipation is more commonly associated with colonic function disruptions or changes in diet following gastrointestinal surgery, not specifically related to the ileum or jejunum resections which would more likely impact diarrhea due to reduced absorption capacities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resection of the terminal ileum specifically compromises vitamin B12 absorption due to the loss of the primary site where the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex is absorbed. This can lead to significant clinical issues related to vitamin B12 deficiency, such as anemia and neurological disturbances, unless managed with appropriate supplementation.

 

Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

 

  • Iron is absorbed in duodenum and upper jejunum
  • Folate is absorbed in jejunum
  • Vitamin B12 is absorbed in terminal Ileum

choices.text: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors
Increased in activity of hepatic lipase

questions.text: The value of TG and VLDL are high in chronic diabetes because of which of the following reasons: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity.

 

In chronic diabetes, increase in hormone sensitive lipase and decrease in lipoprotein is seen, due to which values of TG and VLDL are increased.

 

Insulin has inhibitory effect on hormone sensitive lipase. In diabetes, low insulin corresponds to an increase in hormone sensitive lipase activity. This promotes breakdown of lipids and release of TG, and free fatty acids from the adipose tissue.

 

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase, which is present on capillary walls. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TG and degradation of transport proteins, VLDL and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity which corresponds to increase in VLDL and TG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase: Incorrect because in diabetes, the activities of these enzymes are reversed; HSL activity is increased, and LPL activity is decreased.

 

Option C. Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors: Incorrect because LDL receptor function generally affects LDL levels, not directly influencing VLDL or triglyceride levels.

 

Option D. Increased in activity of hepatic lipase: Incorrect for this context as hepatic lipase primarily affects the metabolism of HDL and to a lesser extent LDL, not directly impacting TG and VLDL levels in the way described for this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


In chronic diabetes, the combination of increased hormone sensitive lipase activity (due to low insulin levels) and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity leads to higher levels of triglycerides and VLDL. This reflects the central role of insulin in lipid metabolism regulation.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about sympathetic, parasympathetic, and motor nerves. Which of the following statements are true? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

 

  1. Sympathetic efferent are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited.
  2. Sympathetic fibers travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain, before finally synapsing and then a shorter distance to effector organs.
  3. Parasympathetic fibers travel a shorter distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to the target organs.
  4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4

 

Explanation

 

The true statements are:

 

Statement 1. Sympathetic efferents are distributed all over the body extensively, whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited. Sympathetic fibers provide widespread distribution throughout the body, innervating various organs and tissues. In contrast, parasympathetic fibers have a more restricted distribution, primarily targeting the head, neck, and trunk regions.

 

Statement 4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber. Motor neurons originate in the ventral horn of the spinal cord, and their axons branch out to innervate individual muscle fibers, facilitating voluntary muscle movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Incorrect. Sympathetic fibers do not travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain before synapsing. Instead, sympathetic preganglionic fibers travel a short distance to the ganglia (which are located close to the spinal cord) and then the postganglionic fibers travel a long distance to reach the effector organs.

 

Statement 3: Incorrect. Parasympathetic fibers travel a long distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to or within the target organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic efferent are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited to head neck and trunk

questions.text:
First part of PCT has which of the following transport proteins? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Sodium potassium pump
  2. Na- glucose co-transporter
  3. Sodium hydrogen antiport
  4. Na+ Bicarbonate cotransporter
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1,2,3

 

1. Sodium-potassium pump: This transporter is found on the basolateral side of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) cells and is critical for maintaining the sodium gradient that drives other transport processes.

 

2. Na-glucose co-transporter: This is located on the apical membrane of PCT cells and uses the sodium gradient to co-transport glucose from the tubular lumen into the cell.

 

3. Sodium-hydrogen antiport: Also on the apical membrane, this antiporter exchanges sodium from the tubular lumen with hydrogen ions from the cell, playing a key role in sodium reabsorption and pH balance.

 

Other Option

 

4. Na+ Bicarbonate cotransporter: It is present in the distal or late part of PCT (Not in the early PCT)- contributes to bicarbonate reabsorption.

The correct combination based on the provided answer is b) 1,2,3, which includes the sodium-potassium pump, the Na-glucose co-transporter, and the sodium-hydrogen antiport, all of which are essential for the function of the PCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proximal convoluted tubule – transport processes –

choices.text: 2 and 4 are correct
1, 3 and 5 are correct
1, 4 and 5 are correct
2, 4 and 5 are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding mechanisms of depolarization, Repolarization, and hyperpolarization in a skeletal muscle action potential?(INICET May 2020)

 

  1. Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels
  2. Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through ligand-gated channels
  3. Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a voltage-gated channel
  4. Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a ligand-gated channel
  5. Hyperpolarization due to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 5 are correct

 

Action potential in skeletal muscle:

 

During the onset of depolarization, voltage gated sodium channels open and there is slow influx of Na+. When depolarization reaches 7 to 10 mV, the voltage gated Na+ channels start opening at a faster rate. It is called Na+ channel activation. When the firing level is reached, the influx of Na+ is very great and it leads to overshoot.

 

But the Na+ transport is short lived. It is because of rapid inactivation of Na+ channels. Thus, the Na+ channels open and close quickly. At the same time, the K+ channels start opening. This leads to efflux of K+ out of the cell, causing repolarization.

 

Unlike the Na+ channels, the K+ channels remain open for longer duration. These channels remain opened for few more milliseconds after completion of repolarization. It causes efflux of a greater number of K+ producing more negativity inside. It is the cause for hyperpolarization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 and 4 are correct: Incorrect. Depolarization in skeletal muscle is due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels. Repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Option C. 1, 4 and 5 are correct: Incorrect. Repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Option D. 2, 4 and 5 are correct: Incorrect. Depolarization in skeletal muscle is due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels, and repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In skeletal muscle action potential, depolarization occurs due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, repolarization occurs due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, and hyperpolarization is caused by the prolonged efflux of K+.

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

1-b . Transthyretin (TTR) or Prealbumin is a tetrameric transport protein highly conserved through vertebrate evolution and synthesized in the liver, choroid plexus, and retinal pigment epithelium. TTR transports the thyroid hormone thyroxine and the retinol-binding protein (RBP) bound to retinol (vitamin A).

 

 2-c. Transcobalamins are carrier proteins which bind cobalamin (B12). Transcobalamin I (TCN1), also known as haptocorrin, R-factor, and R-protein, is a glycoprotein produced by the salivary glands of the mouth. It primarily serves to protect cobalamin (Vitamin B12) from acid degradation in the stomach by producing a Haptocorrin-Vitamin B12 complex. Once the complex has traveled to the more neutral duodenum, pancreatic proteases degrade haptocorrin, releasing free cobalamin, which now binds to intrinsic factor for absorption by ileal enterocytes. Transcobalamin II (TCN2) binds cobalamin once it has been taken up by enterocytes of the terminal ileum and the "Intrinsic Factor-Vitamin B12" complex has been degraded. Transcobalamin II is then involved with the transport of Vitamin B12 to the tissues.

 

 3-d. Haptoglobin (abbreviated as Hp) in blood plasma, haptoglobin binds with high affinity to free hemoglobin released from erythrocytes, and thereby inhibits its deleterious oxidative activity. 

 

4-a. Hemopexin binds to free heme. The haptoglobin-hemoglobin complex will then be removed by the reticuloendothelial system (mostly the spleen).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct pairs are as follows:

 

1. Thyroxine - b. Pre-albumin

2. Vitamin B12 - c. Transcobalamin

3. Hemoglobin - d. Haptoglobin

4. Heme - a. Hemopexin

questions.text: A lesion in which lobe will lead to impairment of hand-eye coordination?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parietal lobe

 

A lesion in the parietal lobe can lead to impairment of hand-eye coordination. The parietal lobe is responsible for integrating sensory information from various modalities, including vision and touch, to create a unified perception of the body and its surroundings. It also plays a crucial role in spatial awareness and motor control.

 

In particular, the parietal lobe contains the somatosensory cortex, which is responsible for processing tactile information from the body. This information is used to create a map of the body in space, which is used to guide movement and hand-eye coordination. Damage to the parietal lobe can disrupt these processes, leading to deficits in hand-eye coordination and other motor functions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal lobe: Primarily involved in motor control, decision-making, and problem-solving, but not specifically in integrating sensory information for hand-eye coordination.

 

Option C. Temporal lobe: Involved in auditory processing, memory, and language comprehension, not directly in hand-eye coordination.

 

Option D. Occipital lobe: Responsible for visual processing but does not integrate this with sensory-motor functions required for hand-eye coordination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The parietal lobe is essential for hand-eye coordination due to its role in integrating sensory information and spatial awareness, guiding movements accurately in response to visual stimuli.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanism in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is mainly responsible for the resorption of divalent ions? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paracellular Transport

 

Paracellular Transport in the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle is responsible for the resorption of divalent ions such as, calcium, magnesium, etc.

 

The sodium-potassium ATPase pump in the basolateral cell membrane maintains a low intracellular sodium concentration and a negative electrical potential in the cell.

 

The 1-sodium, 2-chloride, 1-potassium co-transporter in the luminal membrane transports these three ions from the tubular lumen into the cells, using the potential energy released by diffusion of sodium down an electrochemical gradient into the cells.

 

Sodium is also transported into the tubular cell by sodium-hydrogen counter-transport.

 

The positive charge (+8 mV) due to slight back leak of potassium ions into the lumen of the tubular lumen relative to the interstitial fluid forces cations such as Mg++ and Ca++ to diffuse from the lumen to the interstitial fluid via the paracellular pathway.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active: Incorrect. This involves direct use of ATP for ion transport, not the main mechanism for divalent ion resorption in the thick ascending limb.

 

Option B. Secondary Active: Incorrect. While secondary active transport is important for moving ions, it is not the primary mechanism for divalent ion resorption here.

 

Option D. Transcellular Transport: Incorrect. Transcellular transport involves movement through the cell, whereas divalent ion resorption primarily occurs via the paracellular pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paracellular transport in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is the main mechanism responsible for the resorption of divalent ions such as calcium and magnesium, driven by the positive luminal charge and facilitated by the sodium-potassium ATPase pump and co-transporters.

choices.text: Decreased GFR
Has inotropic effect

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the actions of endothelin-1 except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bronchodilation

 

Explanation

 

Contrary to bronchodilation, ET-1 actually causes bronchoconstriction in the lungs, mediated through ET-B receptors. This makes it detrimental in respiratory pathologies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vasoconstriction: Correct and a well-documented action of ET-1.

 

Option C. Decreased GFR: Correct, as ET-1 affects renal blood flow and filtration.

 

Option D. Has inotropic effect: Correct, ET-1 increases the force of heart contractions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1)

 

  1. On blood vessels - Potent vasoconstrictor, vascular growth, matrix production inflammation → can lead to atherosclerosis, Pulmonary artery hypertension, systemic hypertension
  2. On heart – Inotropic effect, Apoptosis, cardiomyocytes and cardio fibroblast growth and metabolism → can lead to heart failure, cardiac fibrosis, cardiac hypertrophy
  3. In the kidneys - involved in Tubuloglomerular feedback - \ GFR leads to diuresis, natriuresis, glomerular filtration, renal blood flow. Maybe be involved in glomerulosclerosis diabetic nephropathy, polycystic kidney disease, proteinuric diseases, hypertension.
  4. In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors)
  5. In the brain, - regulate the transport of substances across blood brain barrier (BBB).
  6. In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to distal colon (failure leads to Hirschsprung's/megacolon).
  7. Platelet activation
  8. Closure of ductus arteriosus.
  9. Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 gene - craniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.

questions.text: SA node release following in response to increasing blood pressure:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetylcholine

 

Explanation

 

When blood pressure increases, baroreceptors (pressure-sensitive receptors located in the carotid sinus and aortic arch) are activated. These receptors detect the rise in blood pressure and send signals to the cardiovascular center in the medulla oblongata, specifically to the cardio-inhibitory center (CIC). Activation of the CIC results in the stimulation of the vagus nerve, which releases acetylcholine at the SA node of the heart. Acetylcholine acts on muscarinic receptors to decrease the heart rate (a process known as bradycardia), helping to lower the blood pressure back to normal levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Norepinephrine: Norepinephrine is typically released in response to a decrease in blood pressure, not an increase. It is a sympathetic neurotransmitter that increases heart rate and contractility, which would raise blood pressure, not lower it.

 

Option B. Epinephrine: Similar to norepinephrine, epinephrine is released by the adrenal medulla in response to stress or low blood pressure. It increases heart rate, myocardial contractility, and peripheral vasoconstriction, which elevates blood pressure. Therefore, it is not released in response to increased blood pressure.

 

Option C. Dopamine: Dopamine has various effects depending on the dose but is generally associated with increasing blood pressure and cardiac output. It is not involved in the reflex reduction of heart rate in response to high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetylcholine is released from the vagus nerve at the SA node in response to increased blood pressure, resulting in a decrease in heart rate (bradycardia) as part of the baroreceptor reflex.

The assertion is independently a false statement, but the reasons is independently a true statement.
