questions.text:
Assertion: Resting membrane potential is dependent on proteins and phosphate ions.

 

Reason: Diffusion potential can be calculated using Nernst Equation. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are true statements

 

Resting membrane potential refers to the electrical charge difference across the cell membrane of a neuron or other excitable cells when the cell is at rest, meaning it is not actively transmitting signals. This potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions, across the cell membrane.

 

Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

 

 

Where:

 

  • E is the equilibrium potential for the ion.
  • R is the ideal gas constant.
  • T is the absolute temperature (in Kelvin).
  • z is the valence (charge) of the ion.
  • F is Faraday's constant.
  • [Cout]​ and [Cin]​ are the concentrations of the ion outside and inside the membrane, respectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Resting membrane potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions (including proteins and phosphate ions), across the cell membrane.
  • The Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

choices.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure
Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

questions.text: The rise in blood pressure that occurs at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is a result of? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

 

Valsalva maneuver can lead to a temporary increase in blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system. This phenomenon can be explained by:

 

  • Increased Intrathoracic Pressure: By trying to exhale against a closed airway, you create increased pressure within your chest cavity. This can compress the large blood vessels.
  • Increased Sympathetic Activity: The increased intrathoracic pressure triggers the body’s sympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for the “fight or flight” response. This leads to the release of stress hormones like adrenaline and norepinephrine. These hormones cause blood vessels to constrict (vasoconstriction), which further raises blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure: Incorrect. The pressure increase primarily affects the aorta and systemic circulation, not just the left ventricular pressure.

 

Option C. Increase in left atrial pressure: Incorrect. While there may be a slight increase in left atrial pressure, it is not the primary cause of the rise in blood pressure observed during the Valsalva maneuver.

 

Option D. Increase in left ventricular volume: Incorrect. The maneuver does not directly increase left ventricular volume; instead, it increases pressure within the thoracic cavity affecting the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

The rise in blood pressure at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is primarily due to the increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure, along with increased sympathetic activity.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest pH? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Pancreatic juice

 

Explanation: 

 

Pancreatic juice has a pH of 8-8.3, making it the most alkaline (highest pH) among the given options. Pancreatic juice contains high concentrations of bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻), which is secreted in response to secretin. In fact, the maximum HCO₃⁻ secretion in the GI tract occurs in the pancreas, contributing to its high alkalinity.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Gastric juice - Has a pH of 1.2-3, making it highly acidic due to the secretion of HCl by parietal cells. This is the most acidic secretion in the GI tract.
  • Option B. Bile - While bile is alkaline in nature and contains bicarbonate, its pH is not as high as pancreatic juice. Bile serves as an excretory fluid and aids in fat emulsification.
  • Option D. Saliva - Has a pH of 6-7, making it slightly acidic to neutral. While it contains some bicarbonate, it's not as alkaline as pancreatic juice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancreatic juice has the highest pH (8-8.3) among major GI secretions due to its high bicarbonate content, which is essential for neutralizing acidic chyme from the stomach to provide the optimal pH for pancreatic enzymes to function.

questions.text: A 23-year-old hypertensive man comes to the hospital, on examination, BP was 150/90 mmHg, and was afebrile. On further evaluation, serum renin was found to be normal. He was diagnosed with Conn’s Syndrome. All are true about the Conn’s Syndrome except: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

Conn’s Syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by the excessive secretion of aldosterone. Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to water retention, hypervolemia, and subsequently, hypertension. Additionally, aldosterone promotes the secretion of potassium and hydrogen ions via the renal tubules.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conn’s Syndrome is characterized by excessive aldosterone secretion leading to metabolic alkalosis, hypertension, and low renin levels.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with involuntary dancing movements of his right hand. He was diagnosed with rheumatic fever. What constitutes the ganglia involved in the presenting complication? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caudate nucleus and putamen

 

Sydenham chorea is considered to be an autoimmune disease that is triggered by a streptococci infection, subsequently resulting in a hypersensitivity humoral reaction to the infection and cross-reactivity streptococci antigens and human tissue antigens through antigen mimicry.

 

The stimulated antibodies target the basal ganglia brain cells in the host and cause a diffuse inflammatory process in the corpus striatum, mainly the caudate nucleus and putamen.

 

Other Option: 

 

Option A. Caudate nucleus and globus pallidus: Incorrect. While the caudate nucleus is involved, the globus pallidus is not primarily affected in Sydenham chorea.

 

Option B. Globus pallidus and putamen: Incorrect. The globus pallidus is not primarily affected in Sydenham chorea.

 

Option C. Globus pallidus and lentiform nucleus: Incorrect. The globus pallidus is not primarily involved in Sydenham chorea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ganglia involved in Sydenham chorea, associated with rheumatic fever, are the caudate nucleus and putamen, which are part of the basal ganglia.

questions.text: In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled by?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mechanically

 

  • In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors show mechanical coupling involving structural interaction between the two.
  • Excitation-contraction coupling in both skeletal and cardiac muscle depends on structural and functional interactions between the voltage-sensing dihydropyridine receptor L-type Ca (2+) channels in the surface/transverse tubular membrane and ryanodine receptor Ca (2+) release channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane.
  • The channels are targeted to either side of a narrow junctional gap that separates the external and internal membrane systems and are arranged so that bi-directional structural and functional coupling can occur between the proteins. There is strong evidence for a physical interaction between the two types of channel protein in skeletal muscle.
  • It is thought to occur by a "mechanical coupling" mechanism involving protein-protein interactions that lead to activation of the sarcoplasmic reticulum ryanodine receptor by the voltage-sensing transverse (1-) tubule dihydropyridine receptor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chemically: This would imply that the interaction is mediated by a chemical messenger, which is not the case for DHPR and RyR coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Option B. Electrically: Electrical coupling would imply that the interaction is mediated by an electric signal directly, which is not the mechanism in skeletal muscle.

 

Option C. Chemically and then electrically: This combination is incorrect as the coupling is purely mechanical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In skeletal muscle, the dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled mechanically, meaning their interaction and functional coupling rely on direct physical contacts between these protein structures to initiate muscle contraction.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of ventricular action potential in the correct order: (INICET Nov 2022)

 

  1. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels
  2. Repolarizing K+ currents
  3. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
  4. Transient outward flow of potassium
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C, D, A, B

 

The ventricular action potential is characterized by a sequence of changes in membrane potential and ionic currents. The correct sequence is as follows:

 

  1. C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels: This is the initial depolarization phase (Phase 0). When the membrane potential reaches the threshold, voltage-gated sodium channels open, leading to a rapid influx of Na+ ions and a sharp rise in membrane potential.
  2. D. Transient outward flow of potassium: This corresponds to Phase 1. Shortly after the peak of the action potential, transient outward K+ channels open, causing a brief efflux of K+ ions which results in a slight repolarization.
  3. A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels: This is Phase 2, the plateau phase. Voltage-gated L-type calcium channels open, allowing Ca2+ to enter the cell. The influx of Ca2+ is balanced by the efflux of K+ through delayed rectifier K+ channels, maintaining a plateau in the membrane potential.
  4. B. Repolarizing K+ currents: This is Phase 3. The Ca2+ channels close, but the delayed rectifier K+ channels remain open, leading to a net efflux of K+ and returning the membrane potential to its resting value.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for ventricular action potential is as follows:

 

C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels

D. Transient outward flow of potassium

A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels

B. Repolarizing K+ currents

questions.text: What is the stage of sleep denoted by the arrow: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM

 

Explanation:

 

The stage of sleep indicated by the arrow is REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. This can be identified based on the specific patterns observed in the EEG (Electroencephalogram), EMG (Electromyogram), and EOG (Electrooculogram) readings:

 

 

 

  • EEG: The EEG during REM sleep shows low-amplitude, high-frequency waves that are similar to the wakeful state. This pattern is characteristic of REM sleep and is often described as "sawtooth" waves.
  • EMG: The EMG during REM sleep shows a flat line, indicating muscle atonia. This muscle atonia is a defining feature of REM sleep, where most of the body's voluntary muscles are temporarily paralyzed. This prevents the sleeper from acting out their dreams.
  • EOG: The EOG during REM sleep shows rapid movements of the eyes, which is where REM sleep gets its name. These rapid eye movements are indicative of the intense brain activity occurring during this stage, despite the body's overall lack of movement.

 

In contrast, non-REM (NREM) sleep stages (including NREM 2, 3, and 4) show different patterns:

 

  • NREM stages generally have higher amplitude, lower frequency EEG patterns.
  • Muscle tone is reduced but not absent as in REM sleep.
  • Eye movements are either slow or absent, depending on the specific NREM stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NREM 2: This stage of sleep is characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes on the EEG, with reduced but not absent muscle tone and minimal eye movement. The patterns described in the question do not match this stage.

 

Option B. NREM 3: Known as slow-wave sleep or deep sleep, NREM 3 is characterized by high-amplitude, low-frequency delta waves on the EEG. Muscle tone is decreased but not completely absent, and there is minimal to no eye movement. The pattern described does not correspond to NREM 3.

 

Option C. NREM 4: Often combined with NREM 3 in the modern classification, this stage is also characterized by delta waves, reduced muscle tone, and lack of eye movement. The described pattern is inconsistent with this stage as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

REM sleep is characterized by low-amplitude, high-frequency EEG waves, muscle atonia as shown in the EMG, and rapid eye movements as shown in the EOG. Recognizing these patterns is crucial for correctly identifying REM sleep, which is a critical stage for processes like memory consolidation and emotional regulation.

questions.text: Which of the following regulates the body temperature? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypothalamus

 

Explanation:


The regulation of body temperature is primarily controlled by the hypothalamus. Specifically, the anterior nucleus of the hypothalamus is responsible for cooling mechanisms, akin to standing in front of an air conditioner during hot weather. Conversely, the posterior nucleus of the hypothalamus manages warming mechanisms, similar to standing near an exhaust to receive warm air during cold weather.

This dual role in temperature regulation is unique to the hypothalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are involved in the coordination of movement and motor control, but they do not play a role in temperature regulation.

 

Option C. Thalamus: The thalamus acts as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex, and does not regulate body temperature.

 

Option D. Limbic system: The limbic system is involved in emotions, behavior, and long-term memory, but it does not have a role in the regulation of body temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hypothalamus, specifically its anterior and posterior nuclei, is responsible for regulating body temperature.

questions.text:
A patient presents to the emergency department with an unconscious state. An arterial blood analysis reveals the following values:
pH = 7.1; PCO2 = 22 mmHg; HCO3- = 16 mEq/l.

 

Identify the patient’s condition. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic acidosis

 

The patient’s arterial blood analysis shows a pH of 7.1, indicating an acidotic state (normal pH range: 7.35-7.45). The PCO2 is 22 mmHg, which is below the normal range (35-45 mmHg), and the HCO3- is 16 mEq/l, which is also below the normal range (22-28 mEq/l).

 

To determine whether the acidosis is metabolic or respiratory, we look at the bicarbonate (HCO3-) and PCO2 levels. In this case, the decreased HCO3- points towards a metabolic cause. The PCO2 is also low, indicating that the respiratory system is trying to compensate by reducing CO2 levels to counteract the acidosis. Therefore, the primary problem is metabolic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: This condition would present with an elevated pH (alkalosis) and usually high HCO3- levels, which is not consistent with the provided values.

 

Option C. Respiratory acidosis: This condition would present with an elevated PCO2 and a decreased pH. In this case, the PCO2 is low, not high, ruling out respiratory acidosis.

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: This condition would present with an elevated pH and a decreased PCO2. Although the PCO2 is low, the pH is also low, which is inconsistent with alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of metabolic acidosis, both the pH and bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels are decreased, and the respiratory system may compensate by lowering PCO2.

choices.text: Increases dopamine availability in synaptic cleft

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with narcolepsy is prescribed modafinil for excessive daytime sleepiness. What is the primary mechanism of action of modafinil in promoting wakefulness? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increases dopamine availability in synaptic cleft

 

Modafinil is a wake-promoting medication used in the treatment of narcolepsy and other sleep disorders. Its primary mechanism of action is through inhibition of dopamine reuptake transporters, which leads to increased dopamine availability in the synaptic cleft. This increased dopamine signaling promotes wakefulness and alertness through activation of dopaminergic pathways in the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blocks adenosine receptors: While this is the mechanism of action for caffeine, modafinil does not significantly interact with adenosine receptors. Its wake-promoting effects are primarily mediated through dopaminergic pathways.

 

Option C. Activates GABA receptors: This is incorrect because activation of GABA receptors would promote sleep rather than wakefulness. GABA is an inhibitory neurotransmitter, and its activation typically leads to sedation.

 

Option D. Antagonizes H1 histamine receptors: While histamine is involved in promoting wakefulness, modafinil does not primarily work through histamine receptor antagonism. H1 histamine receptor antagonists (like diphenhydramine) actually cause sedation rather than promote wakefulness.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the mechanism of action of wake-promoting medications, specifically how modafinil promotes wakefulness through dopaminergic pathways rather than through adenosine blockade like caffeine.

questions.text: What is the most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleuritis with/without pleural effusion.

 

Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion is the most common pulmonary manifestation in patients with SLE. This condition reflects the systemic inflammatory nature of SLE, which frequently affects serous membranes including the pleura. Pleural involvement in SLE typically presents as an exudative pleural effusion, often characterized by pleuritic pain and effusion that can be detected by physical examination and imaging studies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shrinking lung syndrome: is very rare occurring in 1% of patients. Some association with Anti-Ro/La antibodies seen. No correlation between disease activity, symptoms and antibodies.

 

Option B. Intra Alveolar hemorrhage and D. Interstitial inflammation: are not the most common presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion stands out as the most frequent pulmonary complication in SLE due to the disease’s propensity to inflame serous membranes. Accurate diagnosis and effective management of SLE and its pulmonary manifestations are crucial for improving quality of life and reducing morbidity in affected patients.

choices.text: Leydig cells
Sertoli cells
Seminiferous tubules

questions.text: Testosterone production is mainly contributed by?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Leydig cell

 

Explanation

 

Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells.

 

  • In puberty, the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis plays a major role in regulating testosterone levels and gonadal function.
  • The hypothalamus secretes GnRH, which travels down the hypothalamohypophyseal portal system to the anterior pituitary, which secretes luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
  • LH and FSH are two gonadotropic hormones that travel through the blood and act on receptors in the gonads.
  • LH, in particular, acts on the Leydig cells to increase testosterone production. Testosterone limits its own secretion via negative feedback.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sertoli cells: Incorrect as Sertoli cells are primarily involved in the nourishment and support of developing spermatozoa, not in the production of testosterone.

 

Option C. Seminiferous tubules: Incorrect because while these structures within the testes are involved in sperm production, the cells directly responsible for testosterone production are the Leydig cells, not the tubules themselves.

 

Option D. Epididymis: Incorrect as the epididymis is involved in the storage, maturation, and transport of sperm cells, not hormone production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells in the testes, which are specifically stimulated by luteinizing hormone (LH) from the anterior pituitary gland. This hormonal production is crucial for male reproductive and general health.

questions.text: In which muscles are white fibers predominantly found? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Hand muscles

 

Explanation:


White fibers correspond to Type IIB/Fast Glycolytic muscle fibers. These fibers have high glycolytic capacity but low oxidative capacity. They are characterized by fast contraction speed, high myosin ATPase activity, and rapid fatigue. Hand muscles predominantly contain these white (Type IIB) fibers to facilitate precise, rapid movements required for fine motor skills.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Calf muscle: Calf muscles (particularly soleus) predominantly contain Type I and Type IIA fibers, which are red in color due to higher myoglobin content and greater capillary density. The soleus specifically is noted for containing Type IIA fibers (Fast Oxidative Glycolytic).
  • Option b. Back muscles: Back muscles primarily contain Type I (Slow Oxidative) fibers that appear red due to high myoglobin content. These muscles are responsible for maintaining posture and require sustained contractions rather than rapid, powerful ones.
  • Option c. Gluteal muscles: While gluteal muscles contain a mixture of fiber types, they don't predominantly feature white Type IIB fibers. They have a significant proportion of Type I and Type IIA fibers to support both postural maintenance and powerful movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type IIB/Fast Glycolytic (white) muscle fibers predominate in hand muscles and other muscles requiring rapid, precise movements with short bursts of activity, reflecting their high glycolytic capacity, fast contraction speed, and quick fatigue properties.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is NOT directly measured in an ABG analysis? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Base excess

 

Explanation: 

 

Base excess (BE) is not directly measured by the ABG machine but is calculated using the measured parameters. It represents the amount of strong acid or base needed to titrate blood to a pH of 7.40 at a PCO2 of 40 mmHg. The calculation involves pH, PCO2, and hemoglobin concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PO2: The partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) is directly measured by the ABG machine using an oxygen electrode, providing immediate information about blood oxygenation.

 

Option C. PCO2: The partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) is directly measured using a Severinghaus electrode in the ABG machine, reflecting ventilation status.

 

Option D. pH: Blood pH is directly measured using a glass electrode in the ABG machine, indicating the hydrogen ion concentration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding that while ABG machines directly measure pH, PO2, and PCO2, other important parameters like base excess are derived through calculations using these measured values. This helps in comprehensive assessment of acid-base status.

questions.text: During an 800-meter run (approximately 2 minutes), most of the energy consumed by skeletal muscles to replenish ATP is derived from? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anaerobic glycolysis

 

The 800-meter run, lasting approximately 2 minutes, primarily relies on anaerobic glycolysis for ATP production. This system bridges the gap between the immediate phosphagen system and aerobic metabolism, providing rapid energy through glucose breakdown without oxygen, resulting in lactate accumulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphocreatine: Incorrect. While phosphocreatine provides immediate energy, it's depleted within 8-10 seconds and can't sustain energy needs for an 800-meter run. It only contributes to the initial burst.

 

Option C. Aerobic glycolysis: Incorrect. Though aerobic metabolism begins contributing during an 800-meter run, it isn't the predominant energy system for this duration. It becomes more important in events lasting longer than 2-3 minutes.

 

Option D. Oxidation of fatty acids: Incorrect. Fatty acid oxidation is too slow to be a significant energy contributor during an 800-meter run. It becomes important during prolonged exercise lasting more than 30 minutes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding that anaerobic glycolysis is the primary energy system for high-intensity exercise lasting 1-3 minutes, such as an 800-meter run, bridging the gap between immediate phosphagen system and aerobic metabolism.

choices.text: EDV and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in ESV pressure curve
End systolic volume and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in EDV and pressure curve

questions.text:
If the contractility of the heart is decreased, which of the following is seen? (INICET Nov 2021)

 

ESV: End-systolic volume

EDV: End-diastolic volume
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Slope changes in ESV pressure curve

 

A decrease in contractility of the heart can result in changes in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESV pressure curve) in addition to changes in end-systolic volume (ESV) and end-diastolic volume (EDV).

 

When contractility is decreased, the ventricle is less able to generate the same pressure for a given volume of blood, resulting in a reduced slope of the ESV pressure curve. This indicates that the heart is less efficient in ejecting blood during systole.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is B. Slope changes in ESV pressure curve. This is because the slope of the ESV pressure curve is an index of contractility, and a decrease in contractility results in a reduced slope of the curve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. is incorrect because a leftward shift of the end-diastolic pressure-volume curve without a change in slope is seen in conditions such as hypertension and aortic stenosis, where the heart has to generate greater pressure to overcome an increased afterload.

 

Option C. is incorrect because a leftward shift of the end-systolic pressure-volume curve without a change in slope is not typically seen in response to changes in contractility.

 

Option D. is incorrect because a change in the slope of the EDV pressure curve is not typically observed in response to changes in contractility.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A decrease in cardiac contractility leads to a decrease in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume (ESV) curve, indicating reduced efficiency in blood ejection during systole.

questions.text: Which tongue papillae do not have taste buds? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Filiform

 

The filiform papillae are the most numerous of the lingual papillae on the tongue, but they do not contain taste buds. They are primarily responsible for the general sensations of touch, temperature, pressure, and texture. Unlike other types of papillae—such as foliate, fungiform, and circumvallate—filiform papillae are not involved in the sensation of taste, which is a special sensory function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foliate: These papillae are located on the lateral sides of the tongue and contain taste buds. They are primarily involved in sensing sweet and sour tastes.

 

Option C. Fungiform Papilla: These are found on the top of the tongue and are involved in sensing sweet, sour, and salty tastes. They contain taste buds.

 

Option D. Circumvallate: These are located at the back of the tongue and are primarily involved in sensing bitter tastes. They also contain taste buds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The filiform papillae do not contain taste buds and are primarily involved in general sensations like touch and texture, not in the sensation of taste

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest discomfort and dyspnea. A diagnosis of cardiac tamponade is considered. Which of the following changes in jugular venous pressure (JVP) is most indicative of cardiac tamponade? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Y descent is blunted/absent

 

Y descent is blunted/absent: Correct. In cardiac tamponade, the pressure within the pericardium limits the right ventricular filling during diastole, which blunts or abolishes the Y descent on the JVP waveform, as it reflects the rapid emptying of the jugular veins into the right atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prominent X descent: Incorrect. The X descent represents atrial relaxation and downward displacement of the closed tricuspid valve during ventricular systole. It can be prominent in conditions such as constrictive pericarditis but is not specifically indicative of cardiac tamponade.

 

Option C. Large a waves: Incorrect. Large a waves are associated with increased resistance to right atrial emptying, as seen in tricuspid stenosis or right atrial hypertrophy, not typically in cardiac tamponade.

 

Option D. Steep Y descent: Incorrect. A steep Y descent is associated with conditions that allow rapid venous filling into the right ventricle, such as constrictive pericarditis, and is not characteristic of cardiac tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the Y descent on the jugular venous pressure waveform is blunted or absent due to restricted right ventricular filling during diastole.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones uses receptor tyrosine kinase signaling for cellular growth and angiogenesis? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VEGF (Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor)

 

VEGF utilizes receptor tyrosine kinase signaling through VEGF receptors (VEGFRs). When VEGF binds to its receptor, it causes dimerization and autophosphorylation of the intracellular tyrosine kinase domains. This activates multiple downstream signaling pathways crucial for angiogenesis, vascular permeability, and endothelial cell survival.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin: Incorrect. While insulin does use receptor tyrosine kinase signaling, its primary functions are metabolic regulation and glucose homeostasis, not angiogenesis and cellular growth.

 

Option C. GLP-1 (Glucagon-Like Peptide-1): Incorrect. GLP-1 acts through G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), not receptor tyrosine kinases. It primarily functions in glucose homeostasis and appetite regulation.

 

Option D. Prolactin: Incorrect. Prolactin signals through cytokine receptors that use JAK-STAT signaling pathways, not receptor tyrosine kinases. It's primarily involved in lactation and reproductive functions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding that VEGF uses receptor tyrosine kinase signaling specifically for promoting angiogenesis and vascular development, distinguishing it from other hormones that may use different signaling pathways or have different physiological roles.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about skeletal muscle contraction? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. Extracellular Ca2+ is important for contraction
  2. Ca2+ is released from mitochondria
  3. Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  4. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule have no role in EC coupling
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 only

 

During the contraction of the skeletal muscle, the Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Only statement 3 is correct.

 

Excitation contraction coupling refers to the process by which the membrane depolarization of the muscle fibre (excitation) leads to the contraction of the muscle.

 

The steps of excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle are as follows:

 

 

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes the release of acetylcholine at the motor endplate, which binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
  • This causes increased Na+ and K+ conductance in the endplate membrane generating local end-plate potential.
  • When the local endplate potential reaches a threshold for the muscle fibre, and an action potential is generated.
  • The generated action potential passes inward through the T tubules, via activating voltage gated Ca2+ channels, leading to the spread of depolarization.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fibre releases of Ca2+ from terminal cisterns of sarcoplasmic reticulum and diffusion to thick and thin filaments.
  • The calcium released, binds to troponin C, uncovering myosin-binding sites on actin.
  • Cross-linkages formed between actin and myosin and sliding of thin on thick filaments causes contraction of the skeletal muscle.

 

Steps in relaxation:

 

 

Extracellular calcium levels play an important role in muscle contraction specially in smooth and cardiac muscle, when there is a decrease in extracellular calcium as in hypocalcemia, the voltage-gated sodium channels are activated, which causes sodium influx. The increased intracellular sodium concentration causes sustained depolarization, which may lead to tetany.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 3, 4: Incorrect. Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria do not play a direct role in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule needs to be activated in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Option C. 1, 2, 4: Incorrect. Extracellular Ca2+ is not directly important for skeletal muscle contraction, and Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule needs to be activated in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Option D. 1, 3, 4: Incorrect. Although Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (statement 3 is correct), Extracellular Ca2+ is not directly important and voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule needs to be activated in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During skeletal muscle contraction, Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which is essential for muscle contraction.

choices.text: Forced expiration against a closed glottis
Forced expiration against an open glottis
Forced inspiration against a closed glottis

questions.text: Which of the following occur during the beginning cough reflex? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Forced expiration against a closed glottis

 

The cough reflex begins with a forced expiration against a closed glottis. The pressure builds up in the lungs and, when the glottis opens, it allows for a rapid expulsion of air to clear the airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Forced expiration against an open glottis: This does not occur during a cough reflex. While the glottis does eventually open to allow air to be expelled, the characteristic high-pressure expulsion of air is the result of the closed glottis after which it opens.

 

Option C. Forced inspiration against a closed glottis: Inspiration occurs with an open glottis. A closed glottis would prevent air from entering the lungs, so this does not occur during the cough reflex.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because option (a) accurately describes an event that occurs during the cough reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The beginning of the cough reflex involves a forced expiration against a closed glottis, building up pressure in the lungs which is then rapidly released when the glottis opens.Top of Form

questions.text: Which of the following fibres reach the Purkinje cell directly?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior olivary nucleus

 

The fibres of inferior olivary nucleus (climbing fibres) reach the purkinje cell directly.

 

The inferior olivary nucleus is a key part of the cerebellar circuitry and is responsible for providing input to the Purkinje cells via the climbing fibers. These fibers make direct synaptic connections with Purkinje cells and are involved in the modulation of motor learning, control, and coordination. The inferior olivary nucleus receives a wide range of inputs from other areas of the brain, including the spinal cord and sensory systems, and is thought to play an important role in the integration of sensory and motor information during movement.

 

Excitatory and inhibitory fibres –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Raphe nucleus: Primarily associated with serotonin production, influencing many brain functions including mood and sleep, but does not directly connect to Purkinje cells.

 

Option C. Vestibular nucleus: Sends information to the cerebellum about head position and movement via mossy fibers, not directly to Purkinje cells.

 

Option D. Locus coeruleus: Provides widespread noradrenergic projections that influence arousal and attentiveness, not directly targeting Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus directly synapse onto Purkinje cells in the cerebellum, playing a pivotal role in motor control and learning processes.

questions.text: Baroreceptor provides? (AIIMS Nov 2018
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Negative feedback

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Positive feedback: Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies changes and does not stabilize blood pressure.

 

Option C. Both negative and positive feedback: Incorrect. Baroreceptors primarily provide negative feedback to regulate blood pressure.

 

Option D. Feedforward control: Incorrect. Feedforward control anticipates changes and adjusts accordingly, but baroreceptors respond to changes rather than anticipating them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors provide negative feedback to help maintain blood pressure within normal limits by triggering responses that counteract increases in blood pressure.

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by? (NICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exosome

 

Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by Exosome.

 

Exosomes are extracellular vesicles generated by all cells and they carry nucleic acids, proteins, lipids, and metabolites. They are mediators of near and long-distance intercellular communication in health and disease and affect various aspects of cell biology. These vesicles are enclosed by a lipid bilayer. They are heterogeneous in size (30-2000 m diameter).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosome: Lysosomes are organelles involved in degrading and recycling cellular waste, cellular signaling, and energy metabolism. They do not play a direct role in intercellular communication.

 

Option B. Peroxisome: Peroxisomes are involved in lipid metabolism and the detoxification of harmful substances. They are not involved in intercellular communication.

 

Option D. Genome: The genome refers to the complete set of genetic material within an organism. It is not a structure involved in intercellular communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exosomes are key players in intercellular communication in eukaryotes, mediating the transfer of various biomolecules between cells and influencing diverse biological processes.

questions.text: Which Reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bainbridge reflex

 

Explanation

 

Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. J Reflex: Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.

 

Option B. Cushing Reflex: Incorrect because the Cushing reflex involves increased blood pressure, bradycardia, and respiratory depression in response to increased intracranial pressure, not right atrial distension.

 

Option C. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for inducing tachycardia in response to right atrial distension. It serves to adjust heart rate upward when venous return to the heart increases, ensuring optimal cardiac output and circulation efficiency.

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of evets occurring after p wave in ECG? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. a wave in JVP
  2. First heart sound
  3. Rapid filling of ventricles
  4. T wave in ECG
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-2-4-3

 

The correct sequence of events that occur after the p-wave is 1-2-4-3, i.e.: - a wave in JVP (right atrial filling) -› First heart sound (closure of AV valve) -› T wave in ECG (ventricular systole) -> Rapid filling of ventricles.

 

The sequence of the events in this question can be better understood with the following diagram:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of events following the P wave in an ECG is: a wave in JVP, first heart sound, T wave (Electrical activity first i.e. repolarization) followed by rapid filling of ventricles (Mechanical activity i.e. relaxation).

questions.text: Maximum absorption of short-chain fatty acids produced by bacteria occurs in the: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Colon

 

Explanation:

 

Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are primarily produced in the colon and absorbed from it. These 2-5 carbon weak acids have an average concentration of about 80 mmol/L in the colonic lumen, with acetate (60%), propionate (25%), and butyrate (15%) being the predominant types. They form through bacterial fermentation of complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and dietary fiber components that escape digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Stomach - The stomach primarily handles initial protein digestion and fat emulsification. The acidic environment is not conducive to the bacterial fermentation processes that generate SCFAs.
  • Option B. Duodenum - The duodenum is involved in the early stages of nutrient digestion with pancreatic enzymes and bile, but not in SCFA production or absorption. Bacterial populations needed for SCFA production are minimal here.
  • Option C. Jejunum - While the jejunum is a major site for nutrient absorption, it lacks the significant bacterial populations required for SCFA production. The relatively fast transit time also does not allow for substantial bacterial fermentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCFAs are unique among fatty acids in that they're produced by bacterial fermentation in the colon and represent an important source of energy for colonic epithelial cells, helping maintain mucosal integrity and acid-base balance.

questions.text:
Calculate the net filtration pressure across the GFM for a patient with the data given below? (AIIMS May 2018)

 

Glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient = 6

Glomerular hydrostatic pressure =45

Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure =20

Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure =10

Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure =0
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 15 mmHg

 

Four primary forces that determine whether fluid will move out of the blood into the interstitial fluid or in the opposite direction. These forces are:

 

  1. The capillary pressure (Pc), which tends to force fluid outward through the capillary membrane.
  2. The interstitial fluid pressure (Pif), which tends to force fluid inward through the capillary membrane when Pif is positive but outward when Pif is negative.
  3. The capillary plasma colloid osmotic pressure (Pp), which tends to cause osmosis of fluid inward through the capillary membrane.
  4. The interstitial fluid colloid osmotic pressure (Cif), which tends to cause osmosis of fluid outward through the capillary membrane.

 

If the sum of these forces, the net filtration pressure, is positive, there will be a net fluid filtration across the capillaries. If the sum of the Starling forces is negative, there will be a net fluid absorption from the interstitial spaces into the capillaries.

 

The net filtration pressure (NFP) is calculated as:

 

NFP = Pc - Pif - Pp + Cif


Where Pc – Capillary pressure, Pif is Interstitial fluid pressure, Pp is plasma colloid osmotic pressure, Cif is interstitial colloid osmotic pressure

 

Therefore, Net filtration pressure = 45 – 10 – 20 + 0 = 15mmHg

 

Educational Objective:

 

The net filtration pressure (NFP) in the glomerulus, essential for kidney filtration, is calculated based on the differences between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures inside and outside the glomerular capillaries. In this scenario, an NFP of 15 mmHg favors the formation of urine by pushing fluid out of blood vessels into the Bowman's capsule.

choices.text: Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels
Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channel

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the point marked on the myocardial action potential curve?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

 

Explanation:

 

Marked point on the myocardial action potential curve represents the plateau phase, which is due to the slower and prolonged opening of calcium channels.

 

Two types of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels (T- and L-types) are present in myocardial cells. The opening of the slower L-type Ca2+ channels are mostly responsible for changes in the action potential. The action potential curve of cardiac muscles consists of 5 phases, as shown.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect because it mentions both the opening of sodium channels and the closure of fast potassium channels, which is characteristic of Phase 0, not the plateau phase.

 

Option C: Incorrect as it attributes the phase to the closure of sodium channels and the opening of slow potassium channels, which more accurately describes the repolarization phase (Phase 3) of the myocardial action potential.

 

Option D: Incorrect because the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which helps maintain the resting membrane potential, is not the primary driver of the changes observed in the plateau phase.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Inhibin is responsible for? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibition of FSH secretion

 

Inhibin is a hormone released from the gonads (testes in males and ovaries in females) that primarily functions to inhibit the secretion of Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary gland. The role of inhibin is to provide negative feedback to the pituitary to regulate the production and release of FSH, ensuring that the levels of this hormone are kept in balance for proper reproductive function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibition of prolactin: Inhibin does not affect prolactin secretion. Prolactin regulation is primarily controlled by prolactin-inhibiting hormone (dopamine) and prolactin-releasing factors.

 

Option C. Stimulation of FSH secretion: Inhibin inhibits rather than stimulates the secretion of FSH.

 

Option D. Stimulation of prolactin: Inhibin does not stimulate prolactin secretion. It specifically targets FSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibin is responsible for inhibiting the secretion of FSH from the anterior pituitary gland, serving as a critical regulator in the reproductive hormone feedback system.
